awd_titl_txt: Derived Categories and Other Invariants of Algebraic Varieties
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is focused on a variety of questions in algebraic geometry, loosely centered around the study of invariants, both cohomological and categorical. Algebraic geometry is concerned with the study of the geometric spaces which locally can be modeled as the set of solutions of systems of polynomials in several variables, typically over a field but also over arithmetically interesting rings such as the integers. Such spaces are ubiquitous in mathematics, arising in many other areas such as representation theory, combinatorics and mathematical physics. They also arise naturally in a variety of applications in other disciplines such as computer science and engineering. A common theme in mathematics when studying complex objects, such as algebraic varieties, is to consider various features or invariants which are more tractable yet rich enough to capture meaningful information. The project will advance our understanding of several such invariants and study applications in algebraic and arithmetic geometry.

More specifically the project is concerned with the following topics. Most of the work will be carried out with collaborators and students. (1) Derived categories of coherent sheaves on smooth projective algebraic varieties over a field and understanding additional cohomological features of equivalences between such categories. The goal is understand to what extent the derived category of coherent sheaves, together with additional structure, determines the isomorphism class, or possibly the birational equivalence class, of an algebraic variety. (2) Log coherent sheaves and Hochschild and topological Hochschild homology for log schemes. The objective is to understand a suitable dg category of coherent sheaves associated to a morphism of log schemes. The investigation of such a category also has broader implications for the study of degeneration phenomena for coherent sheaves. (3) Reconstruction theorems for algebraic varieties. In particular, the PI will investigate new approaches to, and generalizations of, reconstruction results previously studied using model theory. (4) Homotopy groups of log schemes and applications to the study of crystalline fundamental groups. In addition to these four projects, the PI will investigate several other projects together with graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
This project concerns algebraic varieties and their invariants, the principal objects of study in algebraic geometry.  Roughly, these are the spaces that can be described locally as zero-loci of multivariate polynomial equations.  They are fundamental in many parts of mathematics in addition to algebraic geometry itself, including number theory, representation theory, and mathematical physics.

The main outcomes of the project are as follows:

1. New results on derived categories, viewed as invariants of algebraic varieties.  More specifically, results are obtained exhibiting conditions under which the derived category is faithful invariant; that is, conditions under which two varieties with equivalent derived categories are necessarily isomorphic or birational.

2. In a related, but somewhat different direction results were obtained showing that in many cases the underlying Zariski topological space of an algebraic variety is a faithful invariant.  This is a surprising new result since traditionally the Zariski topological space has been viewed as a rather weak invariant, but we show that in fact in many cases it captures the entire variety.

3. It is often interesting to study algebraic varieties with additional structure.  Log schemes are an example of varieties equipped with additional structure, which have proven very useful in more intricate arguments in algebraic geometry.  As part of this project the PI has generalized the theory of Hochschild homology to log schemes, and obtained logarithmic versions of several classical results in this direction.

4. Another invariant of algebraic varieties is the fundamental group, and algebraic variants.  As part of this project the PI obtained new results on variation of the fundamental group in families and for degenerating varieties.

Throughout the project period the PI engaged graduate students and postdocs in the projects.  This forms an integral part of their education and helps train the next generation of mathematicians.
